Literature Review: Super-resolution fluorescence microscopy has revolutionized the study of polymer systems, particularly in the investigation of hydrogel nano- and microparticles, known as microgels. This literature review explores the application of super-resolution techniques to microgels, highlighting the advancements in understanding their morphology, internal structure, and dynamics. The ability to super-resolve structures in three dimensions has significantly enhanced the field, providing detailed insights into the complex behavior of microgels. Microgels, with their unique properties and applications in adaptive materials, have been the focus of numerous studies. Super-resolution microscopy techniques, such as STED (Stimulated Emission Depletion), PALM (Photoactivated Localization Microscopy), and STORM (Stochastic Optical Reconstruction Microscopy), have been instrumental in uncovering the intricate details of microgel structures. These techniques have allowed researchers to visualize the morphology and shape of microgels with unprecedented resolution, revealing their deformation under various conditions. The internal compartmentalization of microgels, a critical aspect of their functionality, has been elucidated through super-resolution imaging. Studies have shown that the distribution of cross-linkers within microgels is not uniform, which has implications for their mechanical properties and responsiveness to external stimuli. Furthermore, the polarity inside microgels, which affects their interaction with solvents and other molecules, has been mapped using fluorescence labeling and super-resolution microscopy. The dynamics and diffusion of molecules within microgels are essential for understanding their behavior in different environments. Super-resolution techniques have enabled the tracking of individual molecules within microgels, providing insights into their diffusion mechanisms and the factors that influence them. The combination of super-resolution microscopy with other methods, such as correlative imaging and spectral and lifetime analysis, has opened new avenues for research. These approaches allow for a more comprehensive understanding of microgels, integrating structural information with functional data. The future of microgel research lies in the continued development of super-resolution techniques and their integration with other analytical methods. As these technologies advance, they will provide even deeper insights into the complexity of polymer systems, paving the way for the design of novel adaptive materials with tailored properties.
